Class Check

  • java.lang.Object
    • Check

  • public class Check
extends java.lang.Object
    Check is an object that represents an amount of USD currency in both integer amounts for cents and dollars, as well as it's equivalent total in written english. It contains methods to prompt the user for their desired integer amount to convert using promptUser(), and then is able to convert that amount using intToEnglish(). The class holds the necessary english equivalents for converting dollar amounts, and supports the translation of any USD amount under $1000. It also validates user input to make sure it holds an amount within that range.
    See Also:
    Check(), promptUser(), intToEnglish(), validateEntry(String)

    • Method Detail

      • promptUser

        public void promptUser()
        The promptUser method presents instructions to the user on how to enter their desired currency amount for interpretation, and presents the results of input after conversion using intToEnglish(). It also utilizes validateEntry(String) to validate what the user has entered as possible for conversion.
        See Also:
        intToEnglish(), validateEntry(String)

      • intToEnglish

        private void intToEnglish()
        The intToEnglish method builds an english translation of the already validated and stored cents and ints values. It references english translations stored in private class variables like tens and names. It handles the case in which the user is only translating cents, dollars, or both in combination.
        See Also:
        tens, names, validateEntry(String)

      • validateEntry

        private boolean validateEntry(java.lang.String entry)
        The validateEntry method receives the input from the user and parses it to ints for storage as cent and dollar values. cent dollar
        Parameters:
        entry - - String provided by the user for their desired amount to translate into english.
        Returns:
        true if the entry was successfully validated, false if an error was encountered.
